    This guide is an overview of everything you need to get started in SPGateway.

    Install SPGateway Using an OVF Image

    Use the following steps to install SPGateway using an OVF image.

    Anti-virus and Anti-spyware Verification

    The OVF file has been verified through a custom scan before delivery.

    Import Process

    Import to VMware Workstation Player

    1. Open VMware Workstation Player.

    2. Select Open a Virtual Machine.

    3. Browse to the ICSynergy-SPGateway OVA file, and click Open.

    4. VMWare will prompt you to accept the SPGateway License agreement. Click I accept terms checkbox, and click Next.

    5. Enter a name for the virtual machine, and click Import.

    6. VMware will start importing the OVA file.

    7. Once the VM has imported, click Play virtual machine to start the VM and open a terminal.

    Import to VMware ESXi

    1. Download and install VMware vSphere Client from the ESXi server.

    2. Open VMware vSphere Client.

    3. Enter the server name or IP address and credentials in the respective fields, and click Login.

    4. In the vSphere Client window, select File > Deploy OVF Template.

    5. In the Deploy OVF Template window, click Browse.

    6. Select the ICSynergy-SPGateway OVA file, and click Open.

    7. Click Next.

    8. Review the template details provided, and click Next.

    9. You will be prompted to accept the SPGateway License agreement. Click Accept and click Next.

    10. Enter a name for the SPGateway template, and click Next.

    11. On the next page, select a storage location, and click Next.

    12. Select the appropriate disk format option based on your requirements, and click Next.

    13. Click Finish.

    14. vSphere Client will begin the deployment process.

    15. Click Close in the confirmation dialog box when the deployment is complete.

    16. In the vSphere Client window, click Inventory.

    17. Select the Virtual Machines tab to display the VMs that are currently deployed to the server.

    18. Select the SPGateway VM, and click Power On (symbolized by a green play icon) in the toolbar.

    19. Right-click the VM, and click Open Console to log in to the VM.

    Import to VirtualBox

    1. Open VirtualBox.

    2. Select File > Import Appliance.

    3. Click the folder icon to browse to the OVF file.

    4. Select the ICSynergy-SPGateway OVA file, and click Open.

    5. Click Next.

    6. Verify the Name says, "SPGateway" and Guest OS Type is set to Red Hat (64-bit).

    7. Select the Reinitialize the MAC address of all network cards option, and click Import.

    8. VirtualBox will prompt you with the SPGateway License agreement. Click Accept.

    9. VirtualBox will begin the import process.

    10. Click Start to start the VM.

    Configure SPGateway

    Determine the IP address and modify the host file

    To configure the SPGateway instance, you must add a line to the host file on all machines that need access to this SPGateway instance.

    1. Log in to the SPGateway server using these credentials:

      1. Username: spgw-mgmt

      2. Password: ICSynergy@123

        We recommend you change the password after logging in.

    2. Once you are logged in, the system will provide you with several menu options.

    3. Enter 1 to enter the Network menu.

    4. Enter S to display the running network configuration.

    5. The eth0 section on the next page shows the IP address of the server. Make note of this IP address, as it will be used later in this guide.

    6. Keep pressing Enter until you are back to the Network menu.

    7. Press X to exit the Network menu, and press X again to exit the UI.

    8. Add a line to the host file on the machine running the VM as shown in the example below. Use the IP address you collected above.

      <ipaddress of box> admin

    Example Architectures

    The SPGateway solution is implemented within a customer’s infrastructure, regardless of whether the infrastructure is in the cloud, on-premise, or a hybrid solution.

    Sample Architecture

    High Availability

    High availability is achieved through the use of a load balancer. We recommend that the SPGateway replication information for the load balancer use DNAT and session persistence via a hash of source IP address and source port. Additionally, the load balancer should perform health checks via ICMP or HTTPS with HTTP keepalives enabled for a duration that exceeds the health check interval.

    In order for the SPGateway instances to properly replicate their configuration, all nodes within the cluster must be able to communicate with each other.

    Please contact ICSynergy if you require any additional details or information on load-balancing and high-availability techniques.

    Disaster Recovery

    Disaster recovery (DR) can be achieved by leveraging GSLB or modifying public and private IP address assignments in the event of a DR scenario. Please note that applications must be available as part of the DR solution and that the DR SPGateway must have access to the DR applications.

    External Access

    All external (internet-based) end users must have access to both the primary production and disaster recovery solutions. It is recommended that DNAT be leveraged to increase the ability of the SPGateway to provide accurate audit logs on the correct origins of the user.

    Admin Console Considerations

    The admin console hostname should not be resolvable via public DNS; it should only be resolvable through internal DNS (such as split DNS).

    Introduction

    The purpose of this guide is to walk through the process of setting up the SPGateway Admin Console.

    Set Up SPGateway

    1. Add a new entry labeled admin to the DNS Server that will access this SPGateway instance.

      <ipaddress of box> admin
      This admin DNS entry is required for SPGateway Service Access and should NOT be deleted.

    2. Navigate to https://admin/ page to access SPGateway.

      SPGateway creates a default self-signed certificate. For non-production deployments, this will be appropriate. Proceed past any security exceptions raised by your browser. For production deployments, a valid certificate can be installed and these exceptions will not be needed.

    3. Log in to the SPGateway Admin Console with the following credentials:

      Username: admin
Password: <default password>

    4. Read the License Agreement, and scroll to the bottom of the page.

    5. Click the Toggle Switch to accept the License Agreement, and then click Next.

    6. Enter a cookie domain and hostname for the SPGateway instance, and click Next.

    7. The next page displays the domains that were created. Take note of the domains listed, and click Done.

    8. Enter the host names in your DNS Server as shown below:

      <IP address of machine> <Gateway Domain> <Gateway admin Domain>

    9. Navigate back to the SPGateway browser, and log in using the new admin domain.

    10. After logging in, you should see the SPGateway Admin Topology page.

    Configure IDP in SPGateway

    1. In your browser, navigate to the SPGateway Admin UI.

    2. Log in using your admin credentials provided by ICSynergy Professional Services.

    3. Click the Settings tab.

    4. Click the Identity Providers tab in the left column menu.

    5. Click the + button, and select OKTA.

    6. Enter an app name in the Name field, fill out the Okta Org URL and Okta API Token fields with the value generated earlier, and click Validate.

    7. Once the Okta API Token is validated, the Validated button will turn green.

    8. Click Okay.

    9. The Settings tab will now display your Okta IDP status; verify it displays a Valid status.

    10. Navigate to the Topology tab to test the IDP’s connection.

    11. Click the Okta IDP icon to be redirected to your Okta tenant.

    Add Sample Header Application

    This section walks you through the process of setting up a sample header application with Oracle IDCS through the SPGateway Admin console.

    Create the Application in SPGateway

    1. Navigate to the Admin UI for your SPGateway instance (for example, https://admin.icsynergy.info).

      SPGateway creates a default self-signed certificate. For non-production deployments, this will be appropriate. Proceed past any security exceptions raised by your browser. For production deployments, a valid certificate can be installed and these exceptions are not be needed.

    2. In the SPGateway Admin Console, enter your login credentials and click Login.

      Username: admin
Password: <default password>

    3. Click the Applications tab.

    4. Click +Add to add a new application.

    5. Select the SPGW Sample IDCS Header App option from the left column menu, and click Create.

    Configure the Header Application Settings

    1. Click Next.

    The Settings page provides options with which to further configure the application. For more information on the application setting options, see Application Settings

    Configure the Header Application Attributes

    1. Click Next.

    The Attributes page provides a list of attributes that will be passed into the application. This page also provides the ability to add, edit, or remove any attribute. For more information on the attribute options, see Application Attributes

    Complete the Header Application Configuration

    1. Click Done.

    Ensure that the Public Domain defined in the Configure the Header Application Settings is added to local host file or DNS Server pointing to the VM running SPGateway. 
    <ip address>     <app public domain>
xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx  idcsheader.icsynergy.info

    Test the Sample Header Application

    1. Confirm that the Sample Header App is displayed as Active in the Protected Applications list.

    2. In the Application tab, click the Goto App icon.

    3. Select IDP Initiated from the dropdown menu to verify the application is working.

      If you do not already have an active session for Oracle IDCS open in your browser, you might be prompted to log in to your IDCS account and provide your credentials.

    4. On the application page, review and verify that the SPGW Sample IDCS Header App sent to IDCS match your profile information.

    Add an Application

    This section walks you through the process of setting up a sample header application with Oracle IDP through the SPGateway Admin console.

    The following are prerequisites:

    • Admin login for SPGateway Admin console

    • SPGateway appliance configured with Oracle IDCS tenant

    • Access to local hosts file

    Create an Application in SPGateway

    1. In a web browser, log in to the SPGateway Admin console using your login credentials.

    2. Click the Applications tab.

    3. Click Add.

    4. Select an application type from the list available in the left section of the page, and click Create.

      See Application Types for more information about the provided templates.

    Configure the Application Settings

    1. The Settings page provides options for configuring the application. Review the options and make the appropriate changes. For more information on the application settings options, see Application Settings.

    2. Configure the application, and click Next to continue to the Attribute tab.

    Configure the Application Attributes

    1. The Attributes page provides a list of attributes that will be passed into the application. This page also provides the ability to add, edit, or remove any attribute. Review the default list of attributes, and click Next. For more information on the attribute options, see Application Attributes.

    2. Click Next to continue to the Policies tab.

    Configure the Application Policies

    1. The Policies page provides a list of protection policies (if any exist) for the application. You can create policies to protect resource URLs, create rules using regular expression, and create custom rules. For more information on policies, see Application Policies.

    2. Click Done to finish the app installation.

    3. Confirm that your application is displayed and Active.

    Add a no-auth app to SPGateway

    This section walks you through the process of setting up a no-auth application through the SPGateway Admin Console.

    The purpose of this tutorial is to walk you through the process of setting up a no-auth application through the SPGateway Admin Console.

    The following are prerequisites:

    • Admin login for SPGateway Admin console

    • SPGateway appliance configured with an Identity Provider

    Create the No-auth Application in SPGateway

    1. In a web browser, log in to the SPGateway Admin console using your login credentials.

    2. Click the Applications tab.

    3. Click Add.

    4. Select the No-auth application type from the list available in the left section of the page, and click Create.

    Configure the No-auth Application Settings

    1. The Settings page provides options for configuring the application. Review the options and make the appropriate changes. For more information on the application settings options, see Application Settings.

    2. Enter the following values in their respective fields, and click Next.

      1. Public Domain: noauth.icsynergy.com

      2. Protected Web Resource: https://header.internal.local

      3. Post Login URL: https://noauth.icsynergy.com

      4. Groups: (Select an IDP group that you want to allow access to this app)

    Configure the No-auth Application Attributes

    On this page, review the default list of attributes, and click Next.

    The Attributes page provides a list of attributes that will be passed into the application. You can add, edit, or remove any attribute on the Attributes page .

    For more information on the attribute options, see Application Attributes.

    Configure the No-auth Application Policies

    1. The Policies page provides a list of protection policies (if any exist) for the application. You can create policies to protect resource URLs, create rules using regular expression, and create custom rules. For more information on policies, see Application Policies.

    2. Click Done to finish the app installation. +

    3. Confirm that your application is displayed and Active.

      • Make sure that the public domain defined in step 1 of the Configure the No-Auth Application Settings section in Add a No-Auth Application to SPGateway is added to the local hosts file pointing to the machine that hosts SPGateway. For instance, the application in this example has been created using the public domain: header.icsynergy.info. In order to access this, you must add xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx noauth.icsynergy.info to the local hosts file where xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx is the IP address of the machine that hosts SPGateway.

      • When testing, note that the address bar changes the Wikipedia URL to the Public Domain URL (in this example, https://noauth-icsynergy.info).

    Test the No-auth Application

    1. In the Application tab, click the Goto App icon.

    2. Select SP Initiated from the dropdown menu to launch the application.

    3. On the Results page, review and verify that No-auth App sent your matching profile information.

      If the application is configured properly, you will be able to access this Protect Web Resource through the Public Domain address configured in the SPGateway App.

    Jan 14, 2019 by ICSynergy Staff
